superseding the installed version of GCC is in all likelihood a Bad Idea(tm). if anything, they should install the new version either in a place not in $PATH or with a different name, to only call it when needed.
yes, but intsalling it will default tu /usr/local/bin leaving the default installation alone
If you get in trouble just remove the link in /usr/local/bin

it will, but it means whenever anything tries to call "gcc", the one in /usr/local will run, and that's not very good. Ubuntu packages of various versions of GCC installs binaries like "gcc-x.x" instead
true, and indeed just deleteing /usr/local/bin/gcc will leave the gcc with the newest version there so that is probalby what you whould do
run a which gcc. If only /usr/bin/gcc occurs your fine
